slides.title: Welcome to Oceanography
slides.content:
# Introduction to Oceanography

Welcome to **Oceanography** - the study of oceans!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Ocean Structure** - Zones and features
- **Currents** - Water movement
- **Ocean Chemistry** - Salinity and gases
- **Marine Life** - Ocean ecosystems

> **Fun Fact:** Oceans cover 71% of Earth's surface and contain 97% of its water!

slides.title: Ocean Zones
slides.content:
# Ocean Zones

## Vertical Zones (by light):

| Zone | Depth | Light |
|------|-------|-------|
| Epipelagic | 0-200 m | Sunlight |
| Mesopelagic | 200-1000 m | Twilight |
| Bathypelagic | 1000-4000 m | None |
| Abyssopelagic | 4000-6000 m | None |
| Hadopelagic | 6000+ m | Trenches |

## By Location:
- Neritic: Over continental shelf
- Oceanic: Open ocean

## Ocean Floor Features:
- Continental shelf, slope, rise
- Abyssal plain
- Mid-ocean ridges
- Trenches (deepest: Mariana, 11 km)

slides.title: Ocean Currents
slides.content:
# Ocean Currents

## Surface Currents:
- Driven by wind
- Affected by Coriolis effect
- Create gyres (circular patterns)

## Major Currents:

| Current | Location | Temperature |
|---------|----------|------------|
| Gulf Stream | Atlantic | Warm |
| Kuroshio | Pacific | Warm |
| Labrador | Atlantic | Cold |
| California | Pacific | Cold |

## Deep Currents:
- Thermohaline circulation
- Driven by density (temperature + salinity)
- Global conveyor belt

## Upwelling:
- Cold, nutrient-rich water rises
- Supports fisheries
- Coastal and equatorial

slides.title: Ocean Chemistry
slides.content:
# Ocean Chemistry

## Salinity:
- Average: 35 ppt (parts per thousand)
- Main ions: Cl-, Na+, SO4 2-, Mg2+

## Factors Affecting Salinity:
- Evaporation (increases)
- Precipitation (decreases)
- River input (decreases)
- Ice formation (increases)

## Ocean Gases:
- O2: From atmosphere, photosynthesis
- CO2: Absorbed, forms carbonic acid
- Ocean acidification: Increasing CO2

## pH:
- Average: 8.1 (slightly basic)
- Decreasing due to CO2 absorption
- Affects shell-building organisms

slides.title: Tides
slides.content:
# Tides

## Cause:
- Gravitational pull of Moon and Sun
- Differential forces create bulges

## Types:

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| Diurnal | 1 high, 1 low per day |
| Semidiurnal | 2 highs, 2 lows per day |
| Mixed | Unequal highs/lows |

## Spring and Neap:
- Spring tides: Sun-Moon aligned, highest
- Neap tides: Sun-Moon at 90 deg, lowest

## Tidal Range:
- Varies by location
- Bay of Fundy: up to 16 m
- Mediterranean: minimal

slides.title: Marine Ecosystems
slides.content:
# Marine Ecosystems

## Coral Reefs:
- Tropical, shallow water
- Highest biodiversity
- Threatened by warming, acidification

## Kelp Forests:
- Temperate coasts
- Giant kelp up to 60 m
- Many fish species

## Deep Sea:
- No light
- Hydrothermal vents
- Chemosynthetic organisms

## Open Ocean:
- Pelagic zone
- Phytoplankton base
- Whales, sharks, tuna

## Estuaries:
- Where rivers meet ocean
- Brackish water
- Nurseries for fish

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Oceanography Summary

## Ocean Zones:
- Epipelagic (sunlight) to Hadopelagic (deepest)

## Currents:
- Surface: Wind-driven, gyres
- Deep: Thermohaline, density-driven

## Chemistry:
- Salinity: 35 ppt average
- pH: 8.1, decreasing (acidification)

## Tides:
- Moon and Sun gravity
- Spring vs Neap

## Ecosystems:
| Type | Feature |
|------|--------|
| Coral reefs | High biodiversity |
| Deep sea | Chemosynthesis |
| Estuaries | Brackish nurseries |

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Oceanography!
